item.title: Data reporting - combinations
item.description: One of the issues I occasionally run into is a need to create all possible combinations of two or more sets of strings. For example, I’m currently taking a look at the weather data you can find here: https://www1.ncdc.noaa.gov/pub/data/ghcn/daily/ The data consists of 115,076 fixed-width text files with a “.dly” extension. Each file contains the historic data from a single weather station. Each row of the data consists of the station’s id, the year and month the readings were taken and 31 sets of values with three flags for each value.

item.title: Data reporting - more scraping
item.description: A fellow reporter, Jason Kandel, asked me to look at how to use Google Sheets to scrape wildfire information from this site: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/accessible-view/ I’ve had mixed success using Google Sheets as a scraper but I managed to come up with a kludge that requires manual updates as fires get added to the list (which seems to be fairly often based on my limited experience with the site).

item.title: Data reporting - web scraping basics
item.description: A quick look at web scraping, data cleaning and data archiving This is more of a quick look at something I recently learned than anything exhaustive on the subject. What I learned is how to use html_table() in the rvest package to save myself a lot of headaches when it comes to scraping. Typically when I scrape data from the site I figure out how to grab individual pieces of data, pull them into lists and then create a tibble (data frame) from the lists.

item.title: Data reporting - average percent change
item.description: Calculating the rate of change When it comes to analyzing several observations over time, figuring out the average percent increase or decrease (i.e. growth rate) is a useful but potentially misleading tool. Looking over a city’s budget for the past five years, for example, you can see how the growth in spending and revenues compared to each other as well as inflation. Comparing county population growth rates over a few decades can help pinpoint the ones with consistent growth.

item.title: Data reporting - analyzing occurrences
item.description: Analyzing the frequency of occurrences This is the first in an occasional series of posts mainly geared toward other data journalists. In this post, I’m taking a look at how to calculate the frequency of occurrences in a time-series data. The question is a trivial one, but it does illustrate how data can change your thinking.
